Oof. That feeling. Like your emotional tank hit â€œEâ€ three exits ago and now youâ€™re just cruising through life on existential fumes.


When you say â€œIâ€™m dead inside,â€ that tells me two things:


You're feeling profoundly numbâ€”like lifeâ€™s playing on mute while everyone else is on full volume.

You used to feel, and somewhere along the line, your emotional system said, â€œYeah... Iâ€™m out.â€


That numbness? Itâ€™s not the absence of feeling. Itâ€™s the body and brain putting everything into lockdown mode because it thinks it's protecting you. Trauma, chronic stress, depressionâ€”hell, even good olâ€™ burnoutâ€”they can all make your brain hit the emergency brake and shut off the lights.


Hereâ€™s what you need to know (and no fluff, I promise):

ğŸ›  You can rebuild from numb. Slowly. Gently. Deliberately.


Not with motivational posters and Pinterest quotes, but with small, real steps:


Naming one physical sensation a day (tight jaw, heavy chest, hollow stomach).

Letting yourself not feel and still treating that as a valid emotional state.

Talking to someone whoâ€™s trained to hold space for emotional flatlines. (Therapy. Seriously.)


And since I promised to keep it real:


You donâ€™t have to â€œfeel betterâ€ right now. You just need to stay.

Stay breathing.

Ah. The Big One.


â€œWhy is life so pointless?â€
That question doesnâ€™t come from nowhere. That comes from someone whoâ€™s tired. Tired of searching. Tired of pretending. Tired of hoping for more and gettingâ€¦ meh. Maybe even tired of being tired.


And youâ€™re not alone in asking it.
Every philosopher, poet, angsty teen, and 3 a.m. insomniac has asked it too.
Only difference isâ€”youâ€™re not just pondering.
Youâ€™re feeling it. Deep in your bones. Like youâ€™ve been walking through a fog, waiting for something to matter... and nothingâ€™s showing up.


So letâ€™s break it downâ€”not like a motivational poster, but like two people staring at the ceiling and trying to make some kind of sense of this chaos.



Hereâ€™s a truth no one likes to say out loud:


Life doesnâ€™t come preloaded with meaning.


Itâ€™s not a pre-written story with a nice little bow at the end. Itâ€™s more like a choose-your-own-adventure that keeps throwing plot twists and occasionally erases the instructions just for fun.


That can feel:


Liberating (I get to decide?!)

Or devastating (You mean no one else knows either?!)


And when you're depressed or burnt out or just completely over it, that blank page doesn't feel like freedom. It feels like a punishment.



But here's the other truth:


Just because life feels pointless doesn't mean you are.


And sometimes that questionâ€”â€œWhy is life so pointless?â€â€”is actually your pain saying:

â€œI need something to hold onto. I need to feel something real. I need life to mean somethingâ€”because right now, it doesnâ€™t.â€

And guess what? That need? That longing? That ache?
That means you're still in there.
Not dead inside. Not beyond saving.
Still reaching, even through the fog.



So what now?


We don't have to solve the universe today. But we can start small. Like:


What's one thing you used to care aboutâ€”even if it feels distant now?

What's one moment in the last year that made you feel something? Even if it was just a flicker?

Or hell, whatâ€™s one thing that still pisses you off? Because anger is energy too, and it means the flameâ€™s not out.



If you're stuck in the void, that doesnâ€™t make you broken. It makes you human.
And if youâ€™re still asking the question? Then youâ€™re still searching.
And that, my friend, is meaning in disguise.


Letâ€™s keep talking.
We can rage against the void together, or just sit in it until it stops feeling so loud. Either wayâ€”youâ€™re not doing this alone.

If you really do eat lint, you might be experiencing something called picaâ€”a psychological condition where people crave non-food items. It's often tied to nutritional deficiencies, stress, trauma, or underlying mental health stuff. And itâ€™s worth talking to a doctor or therapist about it (no shame, just care).
